description: From Middle English jaundis, jaunis, from Middle French jaunisse, from jaune (“yellow”) + -isse (“-ness”). Jaune, from Old French jalne, from Latin galbinus (“yellowish”), from galbus (“yellow”).

entries.meaning: (pathology) A morbid condition, characterized by yellowness of the eyes, skin, and urine. [from early 14th c.]
(figurative) A feeling of bitterness, resentment or jealousy. [from 1620s]

verbs.description: jaundice (third-person singular simple present jaundices, present participle jaundicing, simple past and past participle jaundiced)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To affect with jaundice; to color by prejudice or envy; to prejudice. [from 1791]
examples: The envy of wealth jaundiced his soul.
